title: Regions of the United States

vocab.definition: An area with similar characteristics like climate, landforms, or culture
Natural features of Earth's surface like mountains, plains, and valleys
A large flowing body of water that moves toward a lake or ocean
A large body of water that is surrounded by land
A line or group of connected mountains
A deep, narrow valley with steep sides, often carved by a river
A large, flat area of high land
A wide area of flat or gently rolling land
A low area of land between hills or mountains
A dry region with little rainfall and few plants
The edge where land meets the ocean or sea
Land almost surrounded by water but still connected to the mainland
A large area of the ocean that cuts into the land
A part of a sea or lake partly surrounded by land
Water that falls from a higher place to a lower place in a river
Materials from nature that people use, like water, oil, or forests
The way people in a place make, sell, and buy goods and services
How many people live in a certain area
A city area with many people and buildings
Countryside areas with farms and small towns
A famous or important place people recognize
A large waterfall on the border between the United States and Canada
Freedom and rights, often symbolized by the Statue of Liberty
Protected land set aside for nature and people to enjoy
An area with similar weather patterns
Travel for fun that brings money to a place
Farming and raising animals
Businesses that make goods in factories
A big city and the towns around it

teachingNotes: Use U.S. maps to identify regions. Compare and contrast different regions' characteristics. Discuss how geography affects how people live.

sample.question: Name two characteristics that make the Southwest region unique.
What region do you live in?
What landmarks are in Washington, D.C.?
Which region has the Rocky Mountains?

truefalse.question: All regions of the United States have the same climate.
The Mississippi River is one of the longest US rivers.
Alaska has the tallest US mountain.
The Great Lakes are all in one state.
The Statue of Liberty is in New York.
All regions have the same climate.

multiplechoice.question: The Grand Canyon is in the ___ region.
Which region has many dairy farms?
Yellowstone National Park is mostly in:

fillintheblank.question: The five US regions are Northeast, Southeast, Midwest, Southwest, and ____.
The ____ River is one of the longest in the US.
The ____ of Liberty welcomes visitors to America.
The ____ Lakes are between the US and Canada.
Niagara ____ is on the US-Canada border.
A crowded city has high population ____.
Farming is part of a region's ____.
A famous place people visit is a ____.
A big city and nearby towns form a ____ area.

shortanswer.question: How do regions differ from each other?
Why do people visit national parks?
How does climate affect regional activities?
What landmark would you like to visit and why?
